_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.



    The management and employees of Conserv FS, Inc. are committed to the prevention of

    any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur,

     the facility is prepared to work with the Win-Bur-Sew Fire Department, Winnebago County Local Emergency 

     Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release                   

     to people and the environment.



2.The stationary source and the regulated substances handled.



     The primary activity at the facility, which is located at 1925 S Meridian Rd, is the storage of fertilizers          

     for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop   

     production nutrient.  The storage and handling system consists of two 26000 gallon storage tank, 

     nurse tanks, loading risers and associated plumbing.  Access to the site is                

     restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized 

     contractors. 



3.  The accidental release prevention program.



     This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable

     state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety

     Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by

     The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards

     of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration(osha), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage

     and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our   

     employees make up our accident release prevention program.



4.  Five year accident history.



     The following is a list in the past five years of accidental releases that have occurred at the facility:

- We had an accidental release of 40000 lbs of anhydrous ammonia on 06/04/2013. A truck backed into plumbing.



5.  The emergency response program.



      The facility has:



       -  a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;



       -  provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know

          information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);



        - In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the Win-Bur-Sew

          Fire Department and Winnebago County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency.

          Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and LEPC.



6.  Planned changes to improve safety.



     Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to 

     assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no specific safety recommendations for  

     implementation at this time.
